intro: Galium aureum subsp. umbellulatum, commonly known as golden wood sorrel, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a low-growing perennial that produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in clusters. The plant has heart-shaped leaves with a hairy texture and thrives in moist, shaded environments. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its unique umbellate inflorescence. The species is often found in woodlands and along stream banks, where it plays a role in soil stabilization and provides habitat for small insects.
